repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.abstract: Collection relates primarily to Albert F. Murray's career and includes information about his early years working on radio-controlled torpedoes and later his work with the development of television. The material related to television is one of the stronger portions of the collection and includes many photographs, patents, schematics, a chronological history of RCA-Victor, and numerous journal and newspaper articles.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Albert F. Murray papers, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The Albert F. Murray Papers was donated in 1984 by his widow Elizabeth Murray.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Albert F. Murray (1894-1984) a pioneer in hi-fidelity television development, had a long and successful engineering career in both the U.S. military and private industry. Murray was born in Decatur, Alabama in 1894 and died in Bethesda, Maryland in 1984. Murray received bachelor degrees from Maryville College in Tennessee and from MIT and Harvard. Following his graduation from Harvard in 1918, Murray joined the Engineering Reserve Corps and served as a 1st Lieutenant in the United States Army Air Service in 1918. He left formal military service in 1918, but his early engineering work was on a project for the Navy and during WWII he worked with the National Defense Research Committee and the Office of Scientific Research and Development. Murray's engineering career began with his work in 1919 for the Hammond Radio Research Laboratory. This work culminated in 1924 with the design and operation of the first successful underwater radio controlled torpedo built for the United States Navy. Following his work for Hammond, Murray held many engineering jobs including those with the Wireless Specialty Apparatus Co., Raytheon, Jenkins Television Corporation, RCA-Victor, Co., and the Philco Television Co. As head of the Television Department at Philco, Murray conducted the first public demonstration of high-fidelity television at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia in 1937. Following his work for the government during WWII, Murray worked as an independent consulting television engineer based in Washington, D.C. Murray was a member of many engineering and honorary societies, he wrote extensively, and presented lectures about television. Many of these lectures accompanied television demonstrations. Murray's work with early television is the most well known part of a long and successful engineering career.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The dates of the bulk of the material in the collection are 1920-43. The material within the collection relates primarily to Albert F. Murray's career and includes information about his early years working on radio-controlled torpedoes and later his work with the development of television. The material related to television is one of the stronger portions of the collection and includes many photographs, patents, schematics, a chronological history of RCA-Victor, and numerous journal and newspaper articles. During WWII, Murray left his job at Philco Television to join the government. He worked primarily with the National Defense Research Committee. In this capacity he visited inventors and laboratories to study inventions and report on their potential usefulness for the military. Among the inventions investigated by Murray included radio masking tools, interference generators, and Death Ray machines. Please note that there is a folder in the Series Patents and Inventions also related to Death Ray machines.

Murray's work with the John Hays Hammond Laboratory is detailed in a series related to his work with remote controlled torpedoes. The series includes progress reports and other similar reporting tools used by Murray to describe the successes and failures of the program from 1919 to 1924. These reports include quite a bit of science as Murray describes the data gathered during testing and also the engineering methods used to overcome difficulties with design and performance.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into 16 series: Artifacts, Biographical information, Correspondence, Diary, Employment, Graphics, Maps, Miscellaneous, Patents and inventions, Presentations, Publications and writings, Phonograph records, Scrapbooks, Television, Torpedo, and Oversize.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is a small series of material related to Murray's career.

did.unittitle: Atlantic Telegraph Cable Guaranteed by Tiffany & Co. Broadway, NY
Gold card-lifetime member of the Institute of Radio Engineers
Key that controlled the first submerged radio controlled torpedo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material within the biography series relates to Murray's engineering career and includes biographies for inclusion in Who's Who in Engineering and a detailed introduction written when Murray received an honorary degree from Maryville College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The letters in this series mostly relate to Murray's career and include his letter of resignation from the Philco Corporation in 1939 and his work with the National Defense Research Committee that began in 1940. There are a couple of letters between Murray and Dr. W. R. G. Baker of General Electric discussing the advantages and disadvantages of color television. Series V: Employment has letters of recommendation. Therefore, the letters in this series and the letters in that series compliment each other to form a more complete picture of Murray's professional life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The three diaries in this series all relate to the work Murray did during WWII, specifically with the Office of Scientific Research and Development and National Defense Research Committee. These diaries are typed notes of meetings he attended and laboratories he visited. This material chronicles his visits to laboratories and other work for this organization including Murray's work investigating Death Ray machines. Two additional folders identical in layout and content, but without the designation diary were added to this series. These folders are part of Murray's work with the National Defense Research Committee. Using these four folders together allows people to have a good look at the work Murray did from 1941-43.

did.unittitle: Office of Scientific Research and Development

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material in this series is related primarily to his employment with the government. The letters of recommendation are mainly for government jobs in the late 1910s and early 1920s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The graphics are entirely composed of photographic prints. Many of the photographs were originally part of photo albums. All the photographs were removed from harmful mounts, stored in protective sleeves, and place in acid-free folders in the original order. There are a limited number of images that remain with the reports they are associated with. The topics include Murray's work with the torpedoes, television including staff images from RCA and transmitted images from Philco. There are a small number of personal images

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This small series includes one folder with several maps from WWII.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is a catchall series for materials that did not fit into the other series. The folders are arranged in alphabetical order. The folder topics include a conference at American University in 1948, a folder for Edwin H. Armstrong, and materials about the adoption of the metric system.

did.unittitle: Conference American University American Public Relations Association First International Public Relations Institute "Public Relations . . . for a free world", 3rd annual convention
Engineering exhibits of Hughes Tool Company

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes applications and other written explanations of patents and inventions. Only some of the inventions are by Murray. One of the more interesting folders is the one about the inventions of Death Ray machines. Murray has a handwritten description of his experience with Death Ray machines during WWII. He explains that his study of Death Ray machine is limited the investigations done by the National Defense Research Committee. The folder includes descriptions of visits Murray made to test the Death Ray machines invented by various people.

scopecontent.p: This series includes speeches, lectures, and statements most often by Murray. The primary topic is television.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is a large series that includes articles, journals, magazines, one book, newspaper articles papers, and reports. The folder title indicates if Murray is the author. Series XIII: Scrapbooks also has newspaper articles and should not be overlooked if looking for this type of information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The scrapbooks were primarily composed of newspaper articles. For preservation purposes the newspaper articles were photocopied and kept in their original order. In addition to the newspaper articles, the scrapbooks have pamphlets, photographs, and program flyers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material in this subject-oriented series relates primarily to work done by Murray. Much of the collection material as a whole relates to television and thus any researcher pursing that topic will need to review material in other series, but these folders have material specifically and exclusively relating to television and therefore warranted inclusion in a subject-oriented series. The topics include standards, the Federal Communications Commission, service manuals, the history of RCA, and Philco schematics.

did.unittitle: FCC Standards of Good Engineering Television Broadcast Stations (Channels 1-18)
History Development of Television in Research Division of RCA, Victor, Inc.
History Development of Television in Research Division of RCA, Victor, Inc.
Manual Philco Radio and Television service bulletins
Notebook Department 5841 Television and Ultra-high frequency Receivers
Standards: of good engineering practice 550-1600 KC
Standards: Rules FM and TV Stations and Standards and High Frequency Broadcasts
Standards: Television Bibliography and RMA Television Standards
Standards: Television Principles and practice GE Lesson 1-8 Television Reports on FCC Actions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series relates to Murray's role in the work to develop the under-water radio controlled torpedo by the Hammond Laboratory. The folders date from 1921 through 1928, and include the years Murray worked in the laboratory. The material in the series includes reports with blueprints and photographs, a report dealing with theoretical calculations, the employment agreement between Murray and John Hays Hammond, and a patent application for 1928. One of the more useful folders in this series is the overview covering the years 1920-1924 written by Murray about the project.

did.unittitle: Correspondence Torpedo Control Equipment Murray worked on radio problems

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This box contains the same material as in the rest of the collection except that it is oversize and requires specialized storage. The material includes primarily oversize images and posters.
